definition[0]: if a driver pulls in, they move to the side of the road and stop
example[0]: She pulled in to let the ambulance pass.
definition[1]: if a train pulls in, it arrives at a station
definition[2]: to attract business, money, people etc
example[1]: a publicity stunt to pull in the crowds
definition[3]: if you pull in a lot of money, you earn it
definition[4]: if a police officer pulls someone in, they take them to a police station because they think that person may have done something wrong
definition[5]: to earn a large amount of money
example[2]: Within a short time, the business was pulling in over $10 million a year.
example[3]: The government expects to pull in around Â£1 billion from the new tax.
definition[6]: if an event pulls in a lot of people, they go to it
example[4]: The show has been pulling in huge crowds in New York.
